Ha, on some level, I can appreciate the harsh feelings that this game brings out. But it's also a sonofabitch of a game, with tons of chaos and mucky card play that's highly dictated by luck. I can't say I was all that compelled to really play this one again.

And honestly, it would probably play slightly more tactically at two, three or four players, but playing at five (or six, as we did) just seems wild to me. You have a ton of players with a ton of cards, and yet the whole deck isn't out. So you have this massive amount of variables in other peoples' hands, and then a massive amount of unknown cards not in the game.

As the map is tightly contested -- first player to win five territories or three adjacent wins the game -- you want to strategically think about when to go for territories and when to hang back. There's sort of a weird card draw mechanic that you can time if most people have run out of cards, but that is really still dictated by random card luck that people have.

Just being honest, I went through about five hands (over two games) where I didn't see one of the special "drummer" cards or a single "10" strength card. It was mostly a collection of low-strength cards or "scarecrows" that let me retreat a troop card from battle. But those just delay the inevitable win for someone else. I think I drew one "bishop" in those same five rounds, whereas others had several and could just spike my best cards, even when I waited to play them.

It's one of those games where I think there isn't really much of a game here. The map is so tight and chaotic that the person who draws two good hands in a row will just win one, two or three battles, controlling key parts of the map. At that point, you're left just floundering, hoping you win a battle or two, but you're ultimately kingmaking somebody and just kind of waiting for the game to end.

I can dig games with timing and tactics that way, but when the card strength and powers are so wildly swingy and imbalanced, it feels more like artifice. Everyone is essentially punching themselves out at key points in order to win a fight, but the person who has card luck will win one extra fight and probably the game, as there's just not room for bad luck or losing a few early fights. Not with that many players.

Maybe there's a nice tactical three-player game here, but what I played might as well have been Munchkin and just bopping each other randomly. Sure, you can card count partially, but you don't know what is in the game and isn't. And if you have a bad hand or two, you aren't winning the game at all. You're kingmaking and counting time.

Oh, and demerits to the game for no player aids or reference on the cards for reminding what their powers are.

I got drawn to this game because of the box art on the FFG edition...

Luckily, the game is fun. The rules are built on two basic skills: hand management and bluffing. Players all get dealt an equal starting hand (in the number of cards, not in their types), and they use it in a series of 'battles' to conquer provinces in Renaissance Italy. The map on the (small) game board is thus used as a scoring track. However, conquering a certain number (depending on player count) of provinces adjacent to each other can also bring victory. So there's a spatial element to the scoring track, too.

The 'battles' consist of players going clockwise and either choosing to play a card into their active battleline or passing. Passing means they're out of this struggle, but they keep their cards for future use. Battles go on until every player has passed, then the one with the highest valued line gains control of the province. Many of the cards also have special abilities, either augmenting a player's own battle line, removing cards from his enemies' battle lines, or providing bonuses and penalties to all cards played in this battle.

Players' hands don't get replenished until all but one of them has no cards left. Then each player gets to draw as many cards as he started with, plus bonus cards for each of the provinces he owns. The player who has cards left can keep some of them. This means that you have to carefully weigh your decision to play another card or to pass, as playing too many cards might mean you gain the current province but are out of the battles for a few others because you lack the soldiers to fight for you. Both bluffing and hand management revolve around this idea.

N.B.: An added bonus is the beautiful artwork that Tomasz Jedruszek - one of my favorite board game illustrators - did on the FFG edition of this game. It is very atmospheric and beautiful to look at.

2025-02-18:
As you and your fellow players auction for territory in Italy you not only have to contend with the opposing armies. Religious interference, betrayers and even the weather will factor into the upcoming battle. Knowing when not to enter the auction is a key factor as you try and position yourself for victory. New players will be put off by the infrequent card draw, but the game is about playing to the strengths of your hand while avoiding pitfalls.

There is a definite case of too many editions-itis here though. You will have to find the right rule-set that works for your group, but what you end up with is one fantastic experience.
